name: Cartan–Hadamard conjecture
rephrased: On certain curved spaces with no positive curvature, the largest volume for a given shape is no bigger than in a flat space, and the shape must be round like a ball.
implication_form: If a domain in a Cartan-Hadamard manifold satisfies the isoperimetric inequality with the Euclidean optimal constant, then it must be isometric to a Euclidean ball.
explained: The Cartan–Hadamard conjecture, now a theorem proven by Joel Spruck and Mohammad Ghomi in 2019, addresses the isoperimetric inequality in Cartan-Hadamard manifolds. It states that for any domain Ω in an n-dimensional Cartan-Hadamard manifold (a complete, simply connected Riemannian manifold with nonpositive sectional curvature), the isoperimetric inequality holds with the same Euclidean optimal constant as in Euclidean space. Furthermore, equality in this inequality is achieved if and only if Ω is isometric to a Euclidean ball of the same dimension.
related_conjectures: The isoperimetric conjecture for Riemannian manifolds with nonnegative Ricci curvature.
The Soul theorem (characterizes noncompact manifolds with nonnegative sectional curvature).
Finiteness conjectures (concerning the number of ends or the fundamental group in nonpositive curvature).
